Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Dating mineralization in a Carlin-type gold deposit: A test of the Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He chronometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Carlin-type gold deposits (CTGDs) of northern Nevada are the source of most of the gold production in the United States and are thus of major economic importance; however, their geologic origin is uncertain. Various models for deposit formation relate the gold mineralization to different geologic events which likely occurred at different times, including magmatic activity, or circulation of groundwater-derived fluids through deeper gold-bearing units in the crust. Because of the lack of easily dateable minerals in CTGDs, it has historically been challenging to determine when gold mineralization occurred. The result is that effective exploration is hampered by the lack of knowledge about how and when these deposits formed. In this study, a new method of dating these deposits will be refined and tested. If the ages of CTGD formation could be more definitively known, gold mineralization could be correlated to broader geologic processes that were occurring at the same time. This knowledge would enable scientists and explorers to more easily discover new deposits.

Available geochronological data suggest that Carlin-type mineralization broadly overlapped in space and time with the southwest sweep of Eocene magmatism through Nevada. Geo- and thermochronologic datasets are critical to identify direct evidence that magmatism and ore formation overlapped at individual deposits. Indeed, new chronometric tools could greatly expand knowledge of the genetic processes that lead to CTGD formation. No straightforward method currently exists to date CTDG mineralization. Recent studies have explored the use of the (U-Th)/He chronometer for Fe-oxides, but this chronometer has not been systematically tested in ore deposits. The proposed research has two major goals: to test feasibility of the Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He chronometer to date hydrothermal fluid flow, and to use this method to determine the age of hydrothermal activity in a CTGD in Nevada.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carlin-type deposits in Nevada represent the largest endowment of gold in the United States. More than 50 Moz have been produced from Carlin-type deposits in the past century, making Nevada the world’s fourth largest gold producer. Iron oxide and silica-rich outcrops known as “jasperoids” have been used with variable succe­ss as an exploration vector for Carlin-type deposits in Nevada for many decades. Jasperoid alteration is common at Carlin-type deposits, theoretically forming where the gold-bearing hydrothermal fluids silicify carbonate host rocks. If there are iron sulfide minerals in the host rock, the sulfides oxidize when the water table drops or when erosion exposes these rocks to the atmosphere. As a result, jasperoid outcrops are a striking dark red color, and their high silica content makes them resistive to erosion. These characteristics have led many companies to use jasperoid outcrops as an exploration vectoring technique for Carlin-type gold at depth. The use of jasperoids as an exploration vector relies on the assumption that the jasperoids formed at the same time and from the same processes as the Carlin-type gold mineralization, but this assumption had not been tested prior to our study.

Jasperoids do not contain minerals amenable to traditional geochronology techniques, so it is difficult to establish their ages. Thermochronology is a technique that identifies the age of the most recent heating event which has affected a rock. This project tested whether iron oxide (U-Th)/He thermochronology (Fe-oxide He thermochronology) could be applied to jasperoids to determine whether they are the same age as Carlin-type deposits. This is a relatively new analytical method and had never been applied in an ore deposit context. In order to validate our results, we also conducted apatite (U-Th)/He thermochronology on intrusive rock samples from ore zones. The apatite dating produced Eocene ages, indicating that the gold mineralization occurred ~40 Ma (million years ago).

The jasperoids contain a variety of Fe-oxide crystal forms, including platelet, granular, bladed, and needle shapes. The needle texture was best developed in gold-bearing samples, suggesting the different shapes of the Fe-oxide crystals may reflect different chemistries in the primary sulfides. The Fe-oxide He ages predominately cluster from 12.14 Ma – 860 ka, distinctly younger than the apatite He ages and do not appear to record the timing of gold mineralization. Instead, we interpret the Fe-oxide ages to represent the relatively recent supergene or oxidation process, when the paleo water table fell and exposed iron sulfides to oxygen, converting the sulfides to iron oxides. Supergene alteration is important to the mining community because tightly bound gold within the sulfide crystal structure is released as free gold during oxidation, dramatically decreasing the processing costs. The success of the Fe-oxide He thermochronology method as a way to determine the age of oxidation has important implications for many mineral deposit styles, including porphyries, laterites, and banded-iron formations in addition to Carlin-type deposits.
